matrix divided by a scalar(this is a element from a tensor vector) should be supported in gpu. i think so.
https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/pull/653 change ok

i.e. M is a matrix tensor, V is a vector tensor.
expression `M/V[i]` will be failed in gpu, but will be successful in cpu.
as well as `std::cout<<V[i]`.

@pluskid How to fix the problem that both the `plot_network` method and `node_attr` dict have "shape"  ?

Hi,

I think you could do this using `batch_end_callback`. One example is the [`Speedmetor` ](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/python/mxnet/callback.py#L52). You could implement similar callback but do `save_checkpoint` in the function body.

-Minjie
The snippet does that. Please help commit it. Thanks!

Good suggestion. Let me summarize what you suggests:
- Separate dataset parameters and optimization parameters with network configuration.
- Allow command line (or separate config file) to accept dataset/optimization parameters for easy use.
  Do I understand your points?

Also, I think we should unify the semantics of command line arguments of our applications, so once users learn how to use one application, they know how to use them all. Maybe we could do it together with your efforts to re-organizing applications @mli ?
Yes, those requirements are exactly what the users need in daily use. Thanks for your interest!
I think we already support that. The `NDArrayIter` could support `last_batch_mode` as [`roll_over`](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/python/mxnet/io.py#L140) which may be what you want?
@futurely Would be great if you can open a PR on this:) Maybe rename the do_checkpoint to be do_checkpoint_during_iteration
Thanks! Merging. In future, let us think about how to support general cases without switch, take a look at how swapaxis is implemented, we should get some idea
To be more clear, I mean these [`epoch_size`](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/search?utf8=%E2%9C%93&q=epoch_size) should be replaced by iterations.
Please fix python side accordingly
you can merge the dict provided by user if not none. the mergedn dict will overwite existing entries.
These are optional parameters, which are only needed for consensus purpose for distributed training. For single machine, num_epoch is used
You need to use `mx.sym.square` for raking symbolic squares
@winstywang please feel free to merge when you think is ok
The document should be more explicit about the usage of user facing parameters.
@winstywang can you review this

Hi,

Thank you for you suggestion. With your code, you need to do softmax in order to compute accuracy. But this is a redundant computation, since one could directly compute accuracy without softmax. Maybe return some thing like:

``` python
softmax = mx.symbol.SoftmaxOutput(data=fc, name="softmax")
accuracy = mx.symbol.Accuracy(data=fc, name = "accuracy")
return softmax, accuracy
```

is better?

-Minjie
You're right. Softmax is only for normalized class probabilities. The update signatures of `Accuracy` in the two cases are the same.

The problem is on `V[i]`, reading i-th element from the vector. Which is not supported. For a compiler, this means get the value from address `v.data+i`. And the compiler do not know the address is on GPU.

Note that all scalars(floats) sits on registers on CPU, so in order to do that, we need to copy the value from `v.data+i` to CPU, e.g. by allocating a length-1 vector cpu tensor.

So you can do `M/3.0f` expression, or  `M/a` where a is a float(whichi sits on CPU)

Yes, you are absolutely right. The best way is to improve it when we find things that can be improved, so it can always be better? It would be great if you can open a PR to contribute your wisdom into this case and improve the docstring so people won't get confused later

Thanks!
This example is just a special case of the bigger issue in https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/issues/657.

This specification really depends on what was wanted. I will mark this a discussion thread. 

From some perspective, it is cleaner from a modeling point of view to separate evaluation, model configuration and loss function(which we did not). The idea is model configurations contains everything that is necessary for prediction, but not others. Some comparisons
- The current evaluation interface works nicely for users to quickly re-define new metrics
- The current interface allows users to change evaluation metric easily to re-evaluate a trained net
- The current interface is not very friendly for multiple output and loss functions.

The solution can be either what you proposed, or some improved evaluation metric interface that handles multiple outputs gracefully

Again it will be great to have your contribution in opening a PR to help making mxnet better. I see improvement even w.r.t. to this issue is great for all of us, and such steps of changes can again big momentum easier, with your wisdom and code into it

I think so. Just forcing them to be the same is more rigid. But for who is not familiar with mxnet framework, this kind of restriction is very frustrating. For now, I think allowing user to set train `batch_size` <= val `batch_size` might leave user more flexibility. 

So, here is the choice, the rigid one or user-friendly one?

The proposed interface enables even easier replacement of `accuracy = mx.symbol.Accuracy(data=fc, name = "accuracy")` with `euclidean = mx.symbol.Euclidean(data=fc, name = "regression")`.

Re-evaluation is still possible as long as the prediction is the output. `bboxes, pascal_voc_mean_average_precision = get_symbols()` and then `average_precision = mx.symbol.MsCocoAveragePrecision(bboxes)`.

Multiple outputs are not so different from single output conceptually. [Here](https://github.com/rbgirshick/py-faster-rcnn/issues/16#issuecomment-155055447) is a concrete example of combing layers with multiple outputs and multiple inputs.
@piiswrong @tqchen
you can set `epoch_size` to reduce the size of an epoch, whose default value is `num_examples/batch_size`

For web-service, related to #629

@mli I haven't even started yet, so any suggestion you have would be appreciated.  I'm try to figure out how to begin:  should I start with a pre-trained network, or should I somehow train a network on a pair of images alone?

i guess we can first reuse the pretrained caffe models https://github.com/jcjohnson/neural-style/tree/master/models (mxnet can load caffe models)

then try to translate their lua codes to mxnet

we may consider train the network later. we already have vgg model training codes there
https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/tree/master/example/image-classification

do you mean `M/3.0f`is also only work on CPU?
so the only way to make this type expression work on gpu is to fill 3.0f to a matrix which is same size to M.
but the question is whether the generation of matrix of value 3.0f could be finished on gpu ?
Which op generated this? Ideally this should be caught in infershape before forward/backward starts.
LGTM

A very simple version has been done.

https://github.com/thirdwing/mxnet_shiny

Training the model needs much time and tune. I have tried the Lua version of  https://github.com/jcjohnson/neural-style/tree/master/models for producing neural style pictures, and it worked nicely. The lua version loads the caffe model, so mxnet can load the same model too from model.sh and simply replicate the producing script from Lua to python with mxnet.

P.S. since mxnet's unique advantage is memory saving, if later on we can have an mxnet version with slightly simplified network for speed boost, we may be able to shorten the producing time within 1 min. Currently it needs about 2-3 min of producing a 512px image from a GTX 960 using 3 GB memory, if 1024px, my poor GTX 960 goes die. If we can beat Lua version in memory, we can at least produces large images.

![Pogo with oil painting style](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1690881/11313823/ef26f228-8f94-11e5-8757-9e583a2b63d7.png)

Still need to do an extra computation `checkpoint_iters * batch_size` or re-computation when `batch_size` is changed. Simply setting `checkpoint_iters` is more user friendly.

You can try it out, `M / 3.0f` works on GPU. The point is that the `3.0f` sits on CPU. 

The problem you encountered is due to  operation  `float a =  V[i]`. Which compiler treats as a CPU memory load. So you will need to copy V[i] back to CPU first
The same applies to `validation_iters` which can't be set explicitly now.

At least you should have a look at http://107.170.74.195:3838/mxnet/

Then we can talk about deployment in other places.
